Judul: Not the Bauhaus The Breslau Academy of Art and Applied Arts
Abstrak:
Once at the pinnacle of progressive art education, the Breslau Academy of Art and Applied Art
has been largely forgotten. The Academy deserves attention, however, because it was a paradigm
for art school reform in a time when Germany was rife with experiments in arts education. Differ-
ent from its more famous contemporary, the Bauhaus, the Breslau Academy is a study in another
aspect of the avant-garde, and its history helps complete our picture of the complexities of
progressive art and architecture education during the 1920s.
Kata Kunci: Modernist art; Cultural anthropology; Art education;  Visual arts; Arts;  Design as Scholarship
